entry.title: FlightFX Releases DuPage Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. FlightFX has recently released their rendition of DuPage Airport (KDPA) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, a general aviation airport serving the city of West Chicago, Illinois, with a yearly average of 135,000 aircraft movements. â It was built on former sheep-grazing land in the late 1920s by two Chicago entrepreneurs, and the U.S. Army eventually requisitioned it during World War 2 for training purposes. They built hangars and paved two runways, activating it in 1943. The hangar and the runways still exist, although one of the runways is now a taxiway. â Howard Aircraft Corporation opened a factory across the road a year later, in 1944. They built more than 500 aircraft for the military, which was then pushed across the street for testing at the airport.Â â The airport was sold back to the county for $1 after the war, followed by a post-war boom that led to a new control tower, a new runway, and expansion plans that only came to fruition almost four decades later. â Midwayâs example (being unable to grow because of urban development around it) made the administration hurry to purchase more surrounding land and make it bigger, taking it from 360 hectares to 1,100 hectares by 1992, warranting control over all the property surrounding the runway complex and providing a larger buffer zone.Â â It has an FBO offering fuel, parking, de-icing, catering, lavatory services, and a little passenger terminal.Â â 95% of the yearly traffic corresponds to general aviation, 4% to air taxi, and less than 1% to military traffic. There are 255 aircraft based at the airport. â They recently opened a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (C.B.P.) facility on the first floor of the DuPage Flight Center FBO. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, built in coordination with the DuPage Airport Authority, with on-site photography of all major facilities used for reference, custom ground textures, high-resolution photographic textures, custom night lighting, interior modeling of key structures, in-hangar parking spaces, static G.A. and corporate aircraft, reworked landscaping, and ambient lighting improvements. â Itâs available onÂ ContrailÂ for roughly $14.75, requiring at least 2.92 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: iniBuilds Announces Southampton Airport and Release Date for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. iniBuilds has announced that their next project is Southampton Airport (EGHI) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. After initially teasing their next project a few weeks ago with a few screenshots, many eagle-eyed simmers in the community deduced that it was Southampton in the United Kingdom. That was officially confirmed today with a post by iniBuilds on their forum.Â Southampton Airport was originally built in World War 1 for the Royal Flying Corps, and in 1917, was handed over to the United States Navy Air Service for a short period of time. It also served in a critical role for ground and air training for the Royal Navy in World War 2. It was also the site of the first flight of the Supermarine Spitfire. In the modern era, the airport is a hub for regional and international travel, and is home to many airlines including British Airways, easyJet, Aer Lingus, and Loganair. It also serves many operations to and from the Channel Islands. In their announcement, iniBuilds said that: âWe have gone into extreme detail into this scenery and you can see that we have covered a lot of detail in all areas of the airport.â They also provided an explanation on why they picked Southampton, mainly because many on their scenery team, including their Head of Scenery Development are based in Southampton. entry.title: Head of MSFS: iniBuilds Creating A320neo for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. In a developer livestream hosted on Twitch on Wednesday, Jorg Neumann, the head of Microsoft Flight Simulator has revealed that UK based developer iniBuilds will be developing an Airbus A320neo for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 to be included with the release of Sim Update 14.Â â According to Neumann, the aircraft will be âcompletely newâ and is âgoing to sit side-by-side, next to the Asobo A320neo that shipped with launch.â He also elaborated on quality goals, saying, âQuality goal is similar or better than the A310 that you already have and love.â Along with that, he explained why iniBuilds and Asobo wanted to create this aircraft from the ground up: âThe reason why we did that is because itâs going to be more complex, and we didnât want to break all the activities that weâre doing with the A320 already, that would have been a ton of work.â Neumann also confirmed that it will be released along with Sim Update 14, expected to come in late Q4 of 2023, around the holiday season. â This news comes into a market with many different offerings within the Airbus A320 family of aircraft for MSFS. Developers such as Fenix, LatinVFR, FlyByWire, and Aerosoft all either have A320 family products already on the market, or in development as is the case with FlyByWire and Aerosoft. What this news means for these projects is unknown.Â â As of the time of writing, iniBuilds, who have previously worked in collaboration with Microsoft and Asobo in bundling their Airbus A310 with the simulator, have not publicly announced what kind of feature set their A320neo would have, let alone its existence.Â â As further news comes in about this exciting new development for Microsoft Flight Simulator, Threshold will keep you updated, so stay tuned!Â

entry.title: Microsoft Releases Sim Update 13
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Microsoft has released Sim Update 13 for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020, which includes many changes, bug fixes and improvements, and community requested fixes. The main focus for this Sim Update was many small fixes and changes to many facets of the simulator. â The main volume of changes came for the 747-8 and 787-10, which both have received fixes to their avionics by Working Title. Most notably, being the addition of SimBrief integration in both aircraft, as well as the addition of an EFB for the 787. The new EFB also allows for takeoff calculations, which you can send directly to the FMC. Another highly requested feature, step climbs, have also been implemented. â The Garmin glass cockpits have also received improvements and changes courtesy of Working Title. Terrain and Weather Radar improvements have been of primary focus for this update, allowing users to control the gain of the weather radar through the settings pages. â On their September Development livestream, which happened just yesterday, they provided a list of some of the bigger community requests: You can read the full list of the myriad of changes that Sim Update 13 brings on the Microsoft Flight Simulator Forums. â Stay tuned to Threshold for more high quality flight simulation news!

entry.title: iniBuilds Releases Southampton Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. iniBuilds has recently released their rendition of Southampton Airport (EGHI) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving Hampshire with a yearly average of 631,458 passengers. The airportâs history dates back to 1910, when its meadows were used as a take-off and landing spot for monoplanes, then known as Eastleigh Airfield. It was then transformed into an aircraft acceptance base for the Royal Flying Corps during World War 1.Â â During the interwar period, the site served as a transit camp for refugees who wished to sail to America. Hangars were converted into dormitories for them.Â Southampton Corporation purchased the site in 1932, naming it Southampton Municipal Airport, with part of it being utilized by the RAF after 1935.Â Supermarine, a former British aircraft manufacturer, opened a test flight facility there and built a shed. Cunliffe-Owen Aircraft followed suit, later being bought out by Ford and utilized to manufacture Ford Transit vans until its closure in 2013. During World War 2, the airport was transferred to naval command and renamed HMS Raven, spending most of it as a ground and air training facility. It was handed back to civilian ownership soon after, in 1946. Thirteen years later, it was purchased by a racing pilot and began its transformation into a proper regional airport, with a concrete runway in 1963 and a railway station right beside it.Â Itâs served by Aer Lingus, Aurigny, Blue Islands, British Airways (seasonally), Eastern Airways, easyJet, KLM, and Loganair. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with hand-crafted ground textures, a true-to-life landside recreation, highly detailed models of all airport buildings, an up-to-date layout, fully modeled local points of interest, and more. Itâs available on theÂ iniBuilds StoreÂ for roughly $15.85, requiring at least 2.47 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: Laminar Research Lays Plans for X-Plane 12.0.8 and Beyond
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Laminar Research has made a blog post summarizing what is planned for X-Plane 12's recent future, including a new versioning scheme, engine model improvements, improved landing gear physics, and more. â With the recently shipped 12.07, Laminar included three months' worth of rendering engine improvements, new cirrus clouds, lower VRAM footprint, improved cloud rendering, and OpenXR integration. For the next update, they have already laid out most of the futures that will ship with it. â The upcoming patch will bring a new naming scheme, giving Laminar "more numbers to play with," as the previous two digits could only go so far and, therefore, limit the number of patches they could potentially churn out. â They expect a beta build to be ready in a week or two, focusing on improving the flight model, networking/multi-monitor, and tools for using X-Plane with projectors: projector warping/blending will be available for X-Plane Professional license owners. â With data from Pratt & Whitney and Phillip Ringler, Austin Meyer has improved how the platform simulates engine performance, with jets, turboprops, and reciprocating engines following real-world figures more closely. â The landing gear physics was also improved, with better wheel inertia, weld modeling, and ABS revisions, making sure it stops the wheels from locking realistically. â Last but not least, jet aircraft in X-Plane 12 will now accurately simulate how jets use their fuel to cool their oil, with the oil heating the fuel and its consequent dissipation through the wing's skin, operating as a radiator. â They have also laid out plans for 12.1.0, bringing real weather improvements, cloud shadows on the water, better bloom lighting effects, robust contrast adaptive sharpening, softer ground shadows, MSAA improvements, improved CPU performance, and better water opacity. â They finish with a price hike announcement, from $59.99 to $79.99, allowing Laminar to expand its team and warrant its future development. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â
